review_title: Poor leadership and Human Resources openly lie to cover themselves

pros: Coworkers are good people. Lots of decent folks.
cons: Leadership will openly violate state and federal policy. Human Resources will open lie to protect leadership and the company. Bottom line is they dot care about employees. Toxic workplace trickles down from executive leadership. Don't go to Human Resources with legitimate concerns of workplace harassment from leadership, sexual harassment, FMLA violations-they (HR) will side with leadership to facilitate your exit from the organization.

pros: Good pay, good benefits, tremendous support for work/life balance. I never missed an event at my kids' schools. Positive environment. May work-from-home options.
cons: Because people really like working here, it can be slow going for salary and position advancement. Since it's a not-for-profit, the finance people are very comfortable with capping or freezing salary increases. This is the only reason I considered leaving.

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse (LVN) in Fresno, CA
pros: Emergency Dept co-workers vibe well with each other and attempt to help each other out. This is the best place for a LVN to reach their scope of practice potential. You get what you give. If you are on the lazier side, they will keep you on easy assignments. If you are a go-getter, they will use you to your potential and give you a team of 4-5 patients. You get the IV skills, you get the exposure to sick patients, and your critical thinking skills will exceed any other facility LVN.
cons:
Pay, benefit cost, short staffed... 
This is a tough place to work and the pay isn't going to make you feel like, "well at least the money is good", when you are having a hard day. Expect to be on your feet your entire shift. You will be doing your job, the social workers job, the CNA's job, and housekeeping too...
RN's typically get sign-on bonuses and other bonuses that don't pertain to the LVN's.
Benefits for myself and my children costs about $450/month

pros: Cool t-shirts every year for hospital week.
cons: Most money goes to unnecessary stuff.

pros: learn a lot, can go anywhere after fully trained at this hospital
cons: worked in the ER, must work your way up to treating higher acuity patients which can make it difficult to take your experience somewhere else before you are fully trained which can take 2 years

job_title: Medical Social Worker in Fresno, CA

job_title: Environmental Services Technician in Fresno, CA
pros: Benefits, gate way to other departments
cons: Underpaid, bottom of the chain, nurses/PCA/surgical assistants pity you, they don’t like you to use “their” break rooms & time clocks even if you’re in that area! Everyone has fun stuff for their department appreciation week we never get anything nice/cool.

review_title: Revolving door, but has great team
pros:
The team I worked with most directly was very knowledgeable and a pleasure to work with. Benefits were affordable. Pay was reasonable, especially with lower cost of living with respect to other California cities. High level of independence. Emphasized good work life balance. 

Overall the company tried to be supportive and management is willing to provide technological solutions when possible, including covering continuing education etc.
cons:
They offer a binding contract for relocation/retention but few employees ever stay for the full terms. The handful of employees that have stayed long-term are overworked, underpaid, disgruntled, and inflexible. 

The Central Valley is economically depressed. Although this makes California living in Fresno more affordable, it does not make it a great place to uproot a family to. Area is fairly conservative which can influence prenatal care and patient access.

High level of independence can lead to isolated work environment and potential for poor work-life-balance. Given high turn-over rate, no significant career ladder has been established and employee hierarchy can feel inflexible. There is tight knit circle of long-term employees who gossip about those who are not in the circle and who can make seeking help/support difficult.

Team wants diversity and inclusion for surface level reasons like ability to talk with patients/reducing need for translators. Actual buy-in and interest in diverse employees' interests and existence as whole people (beyond just being able to speak Spanish etc) seems variable from manager to manager and department to department.

pros: Knowledgeable employees willing to teach.
cons: Short staffed at times but neighbors always wiling to help.

pros:
•PTO accrues quickly
•Some coworkers become friends
•Free T-shirt once a year 
•Free holiday meal on thanksgiving/Christmas 
•When management has catered food for their meetings, they'll let us have the scraps when they're finished.
cons: Very busy and unnecessarily stressful for what the basic job should entail. Before becoming employed they make the pharmacy technicians sign a waiver saying that they will work 10 hour days with no overtime pay, and that you cannot sue or participate in any class action lawsuit against them for any reason. They pay the pharmacists overtime for their 10 hour shifts, and they pay the RN's overtime if their shift is over 8 hours. They totally screw the Pharm techs and you start feeling like a slave. Did I mention our hourly pay is significantly lower than the average Pharm tech salary in our area? Yet it is the busiest and most specialized critical care hospital in the Central Valley. It's not all about money though, the pharmacy environment is generally chaotic and completely inefficient in terms of workflow. The consensus within is that you do not want to work in the IV room, making chemo or in the NICU satellite pharmacy. Most hospitals pay more for this type of specialized tech service, but not at good ol' CRMC-that would make too much sense, facilitate growth, and possibly foster professional development, and nobody likes those things.

job_title: Clinical Systems Manager in Fresno, CA
pros:
Please forgive if this gets posted twice as the screen and may have posted this wrongfully.
At Community, I had some of the best coworkers a person could hope to find--good hearted, committed, intelligent, caring, honest, hard working, and highly professional.  And some of the management was also among the best even if I cannot say the same for all of management.
cons: I believe some of management including HR and the legal team and senior management are not above engaging on political assassinations, retaliation, and firing when employees report ethics issues.  I was disciplined and fired for the first time in my life at age 58 after reporting what I felt was a serious ethics issue that needed to be addressed.  An article in the local newspaper carried another story of someone who reported a heart surgeon who walked out in the middle of an open heart surgery and allegedly was fired and threatened with a law suit.

review_title: As good as downtown Fresno can get...
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Fresno, CA
pros: Good infrastructure and technology available to staff.  Really glad they had Epic, even if it's a lower tier version of it.  Good security and support.
cons: Fresno patient population -- they're just terrible. Whether it's the accumulation of Greyhound therapy or a combination of regional health risks and socioeconomic storms, they are by far the most difficult population I have had to care for.

review_title: Pick your job field or department wisely...
pros: If your a RN, or other licensed medical staff like LVN, X-ray tech and the various sub-fields like CT, ultrasound, etc., you will be treated decently. Pay is good, the benefits are decent like 401(k)/403(b) options, health care coverage is decent as well. If you are support staff it varies. Medical support staff like nursing assistants (CNA's or EMT's if work in the ER) or EKG techs due to being in patient care setting are granted extra pay incentives for being part of patient care. If you have to settle for facility support positions like security, housekeeping, maintenance, etc. Consider those positions a foot in the door so you can begin or finish your ongoing education for those with the intention of jumping over to a patient care position..
cons: Pay regardless of your position is good but the lowest for the area when compared to other organizations in the area. The health care benefits are decent but have diminished over the years as the company has tried to do cut backs where possible. Its better than nothing and better than the "Obama Care" coverage but again depending on your health requirements it can cause you more unneeded headaches than you would expect. Management and Administration I have found seems to all share the common goal of making money, or minimizing losses and maximizing efficiency...Quality of patient care is unfortunately considerably farther down on the list, and frankly unacceptable since that is the primary role. Also, employee's who are outspoken and provide CONSTRUCTIVE feedback to long standing problems or problems starting to surface aren't welcomed with open ears and usually get a disciplinary form of a reminder to just be a mindless, mute puppet that comes to work does their job and goes home. Also, as far as advancement goes... the word joke basically sums it up... nepotism, cronyism, etc all determines who moves up where and how fast.. job performance, proven track record of solid work history' things you want to thing would be determining factors are not. Extremely political and again another reason why the quality of patient care is in the gutter...

review_title: Making a difference in my the community that raised me
pros: I identify with the mission of CMC to Promote Health and Health Education.  Community Medical Centers delivers the best possible care with limited resources often uncompensated as a safety net hospital network.
cons: Challenging time to be in healthcare with the very unpredictable government funding models being driven by a centralized policy maker in Washington who is often out of touch with our local population needs.

pros:
Before 2005 this was a little hospital in the middle of orange groves.  There were some great OB doctors and surgeons practicing there to make it a cute boutique for those services.
Now you can’t recognize the place.  It is a beautiful, clean, and well maintained facility with a cafeteria that does better than many restaurants.  They have 20 operating rooms and a booming outpatient service.  It is the private physician’s choice place of practice.
I took an employment opportunity here leaving the larger Fresno facility.  I was impressed with the leadership from the (Castro) CEO to the people I work with.  
We just had a surprise TJC inspection several months before we expected them to show when we were the busies we have ever been and passed without issues and an estimated 98.6%.
One thing that took me back is the mantra “The Clovis Way.”  Coming from the systems larger (3X) facility I kept thinking what the heck is this?
I have caught on.  The CEO wants Clovis Community Medical Center to be an inviting tranquil setting where patients and physicians want to go.  The staff feel the support and pride.  The halls are full of smiles and polite greetings.  Even the TJC surveyors mentioned they got it after 3 days (5 months for me).
It is not a place to go if you want to sit around and collect a check.  The staff may be smiling but they also work hard and take pride in their work.
cons: Some of the surrounding hospitals will buy CMC staff and happiness with super high salaries that seam unsustainable in the long run.  The ones that leave say the job sucks but they pay me a lot.

pros: Great family oriented company to work for, can't say enough about the amazing medical and vacation benefits that they offer.
cons: There aren't really any cons to working here once you're able to get in.  Management has been amazing with working around family issues, training was good and time to adjust to the new job was very good as well.

pros: One of the most important hospitals in the Central Valley. Undergoing much needed infrastructure improvements. Continuously recruiting physician specialists. Excellent marketing and propaganda department.
cons: Poor, unqualified management resulting in high employee dissatisfaction and good nurses leaving. Constantly understaffed and nurses go over patient ratio. Lowest compensation when compared to other health care facilities. Take too much pride in its affiliation with UCSF school of medicine, neglects and undervalues the nursing profession.

pros:
Care is provided to all.  CRMC is moving forward with expansion to be the ones capable of meeting the service needs of the region.  CRMC is a fantastic place to learn because of the variety of conditions treated.  Senior leadership has voiced commitment to growing into the mega facility that the central valley needs.
CMC does listen to patients, staff, and physicians.
cons: Other facilities in the region neglect those in need and leave all the hard work for CRMC.  Growing  takes time.

pros: Great freedom to contribute to performance improvements.  Sincere and demonstrated community enrichment priorities.  Supports equal opportunity and diversity.  Committed to employee exceptional and extensive on the job training and educational development.
cons: Heavy workloads due to understaffing issues.  Budget challenges that contribute to management long hours.  Teaching environment causes high turnover in strategic direct customer service areas.

review_title: Nice group of people to work with.

cons: Hourly employee.  I have to punch a clock.  I cannot work from home.

job_title: New Grad Registered Nurse in Fresno, CA
pros: Great experience. My department is flexible. I get to see a variety of floors. I don't deal with politics. It's teaching hospital.
cons: Noncompliant patients. Unpleasant patients. Most of the time you're over guided. Late lunch sometimes. Management can be unsupportive. Not enough staff.

review_title: Healthcare Changes affecting patients and workers
pros: Physicians and co-workers are the best.
cons: With the changes in healthcare reimbursement it seems administration is not being proactive instead reactive. To many good employees laid off over the last 2 years.

pros: Good place to work, teaching hospital.
cons: Low pay scales and budget constraints that affect patient care while upper management receives large bonuses.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Toms River, NJ
pros: Essentially a cohesive atmosphere, CMC has  a good system for on line mandatory education, employee cost for benefits are reasonable
cons:
Has had some nursing layoffs in addition to other occupations as well.
There was some union bashing activity by administration

pros: Great teaching hospital.  Serves all patients, regardless of pay status.
cons: Lower pay than that of the competition.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Fresno, CA
pros: Challenging, variable patient population with high acuity. Great place to learn.
cons: Terrible corporation that doesn’t look out for nursing. Human Resources is a joke - they look out for the corporation and don’t care about the employees. Managers and directors in positions yet they don’t have a clue. High turnaround forces units to hire inexperienced nurses resulting in an unsafe environment for experienced nurses and clinical supervisors.

pros: Great facility if you want to learn and move up.
cons: Poor pay, facility needs to increase pay in order to keep the good nurses.

review_title: Many different areas to work in. Great differential for night and weekends
pros: Great experience on all levels of the hospital. Opportunity for growth is definitely available.
cons: Stressful environment. The patient's here can be very sick and at times combative.

pros: Great company to work for. Management was very supportive and flexible. Nice pension and benefits.
cons: Parking needs to be expanded.

pros: Great hours, great job and great working conditions.
cons: Statements were made against me due to a political move from the corporate office.

review_title: Lots of opportunities at this big hospital
pros: Great place to learn what nursing is all about.
cons: Workload has increased gradually over time. Overtime is frowned upon. This makes for increased stress levels in an already stressful job.

pros: Staff overall are very friendly and work well together
cons: Lower paying hospital in the valley, management doesn't really get involved

review_title: Great place to obtain extensive job experience.

pros: Great people to work with. Lots of change. Location is great for families who love the outdoors.
cons: Limited growth opportunities. Change control is challenging. Always doing more with the same resources.

pros: great team work, health benefits and overall great care to their patients
cons: Very busy department but at times can be short staffed

pros: There is a lot of over-time available for 1 on 1.
cons: Always short staff, huge turn over rate, and nurses are rude!

pros: Lots of learning and the company supports you in your education. Lots of specialties to choose from. CRMC ED and ICU’s are prestigious to work in.
cons: The demographic is exhausting.

pros: One good thing is their is always lots of over-time do to always being short staffed.
cons: Belittling people gives them some kind of satisfaction.Hostile environment.  Operating by family and friends Constantly judged by personal life style instead of job performance, you have to be a YES MAMM and agree with anything they say.
